Award.AwardTitle: Prediction and Control of Tungsten and Titanium Dioxide Sintering and Processing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Sintering, or consolidating powders to useful parts by firing, is one of the oldest and most commonly-used materials processing and fabrication methods. Yet, much is unknown about the physical processes that control sintering mechanisms. Using tungsten and titanium dioxide as the initial model systems, this award supports fundamental research of sintering and materials processing. The knowledge generated from this research will help to predict and control the fabrication processing of both structural alloys and functional ceramics, with applications in energy, aerospace, automotive, and other industries. Education and outreach activities are integrated with the research to inspire and mentor students at various levels, while promoting education diversity by engaging students with different backgrounds and underrepresented groups.

This project aims to achieve fundamental understandings of the solid-state activated sintering phenomenon. It has been known for more than half a century that adding a small amount of certain sintering aids can help to substantially enhance the densification rates in the solid state, similar to the well-understood phenomenon of liquid-phase sintering. However, the exact mechanism for this so-called "solid-state activated sintering" is not fully understood. A series of recent studies suggests that this phenomenon is due to enhanced mass transport in the sintering-aid induced (based), premelting-like, intergranular films that are thermodynamically stabilized below the bulk solidus lines. Using tungsten and titanium dioxide as the initial model metallic and ceramic systems, fundamental understandings of this phenomenon are achieved via a combination of sintering experiments, materials characterization, and thermodynamic modeling. Furthermore, a novel type of lambda-diagrams are developed and further extended to predict the thermodynamic tendency for general grain boundaries in polycrystalline materials to disorder at high temperatures; such diagrams can be used to forecast sintering behaviors, as well as other materials fabrication processing and properties.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sintering, or consolidating powders to useful parts by firing, is one of the oldest and most commonly-used materials processing and fabrication methods. Yet, the physical processes that control sintering mechanisms is not completely understood. Specifically, it has been known for more than half a century that adding a small amount of certain sintering aids can help to substantially enhance the densification rates in the solid state, akin to the well-understood phenomenon of liquid-phase sintering but without the presence of a bulk liquid phase. However, the exact mechanism for this so-called "solid-state activated sintering" is not fully understood.

In this NSF project, using titanium dioxide and tungsten as the model ceramic and metallic systems, fundamental understandings of this phenomenon have been achieved via a combination of sintering experiments, materials characterization, and thermodynamic modeling.

Researchers at University of California, San Diego, conducted careful experiments to unequivocally confirm that the low-temperature densification of CuO-doped TiO2 is a case of solid-state activated sintering. Furthermore, the stabilization of nanoscale liquid-like interfacial films at grain boundaries (i.e., internal interfaces in polycrystalline solids) well below the bulk “melting” (eutectic) temperature was observed by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). Consequently, the solid-state activated sintering in this system was attributed to the enhanced mass transport in this nanometer-thick liquid-like complexion (a.k.a. interfacial liquid-like phase that is two-dimensional thermodynamically), which can form when the bulk liquid phase is not yet stable. This result has solved a mystery that puzzled the ceramics and materials community for decades.  

In a further theoretical and modeling thrust, researchers have computed a more accurate phase diagram for the TiO2-CuO system based on the new experimental data. Subsequently, a grain boundary diagram has also been computed to represent the thermodynamic tendency for general grain boundaries in CuO-doped TiO2 to disorder. Experiments have verified the model predictions. In general, these computed grain boundary diagrams can be used to guide the design of optimal sintering recipes. In this NSF project, such grain boundary diagrams have also been computed for several tungsten based binary and ternary refractory alloys, which can be utilized to determine the relative effectiveness of various sintering aids.

The knowledge generated from this NSF project will help to predict and control the activated sintering processing of both refractory alloys and functional ceramics, with applications in energy, aerospace, automotive, and other industries. As one specific example of many potential industrial applications, low-temperature sintering of titanium dioxide or other dielectric materials have important applications in the so-called “low-temperature co-fired ceramic (LTCC)” technology to fabricate capacitors, inductors, resistors, transformers, and hybrid circuits.

This NSF project has inspired, educated, and mentored nine undergraduate researchers and six Hispanic high-school students via involving them in this cutting-edge research. The principle investigator and graduate students working on this project also hosted lab tours during the UCSD Engineering Exploration Day to introduce this NSF project and related research facilities to community high-school and middle-school students with diversifying background.


Last Modified: 05/28/2018
Modified by: Jian Luo

Image
  • A high-resolution transmission electron micrograph of a ~0.9-nm-thick, CuO-based, liquid-like, interfacial film that formed below the bulk melting (or eutectic) temperature to enable activated sintering of TiO2 at a low temperature [Nie et al., Acta. Mater., 130 (2017) 329].
    Jiuyuan Nie and Jian Luo, UCSD
    Public Domain
    Jian Luo
    A nanoscale liquid-like interfacial film as the root cause of activated sintering
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Sintering, or consolidating powders to useful parts by firing, is one of the oldest and most commonly-used materials processing and fabrication methods. Yet, the physical processes that control sintering mechanisms is not completely understood. Specifically, it has been known for more than half a century that adding a small amount of certain sintering aids can help to substantially enhance the densification rates in the solid state, akin to the well-understood phenomenon of liquid-phase sintering but without the presence of a bulk liquid phase. However, the exact mechanism for this so-called "solid-state activated sintering" is not fully understood. In this NSF project, using titanium dioxide and tungsten as the model ceramic and metallic systems, fundamental understandings of this phenomenon have been achieved via a combination of sintering experiments, materials characterization, and thermodynamic modeling. Researchers at University of California, San Diego, conducted careful experiments to unequivocally confirm that the low-temperature densification of CuO-doped TiO2 is a case of solid-state activated sintering. Furthermore, the stabilization of nanoscale liquid-like interfacial films at grain boundaries (i.e., internal interfaces in polycrystalline solids) well below the bulk "melting" (eutectic) temperature was observed by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). Consequently, the solid-state activated sintering in this system was attributed to the enhanced mass transport in this nanometer-thick liquid-like complexion (a.k.a. interfacial liquid-like phase that is two-dimensional thermodynamically), which can form when the bulk liquid phase is not yet stable. This result has solved a mystery that puzzled the ceramics and materials community for decades. In a further theoretical and modeling thrust, researchers have computed a more accurate phase diagram for the TiO2-CuO system based on the new experimental data. Subsequently, a grain boundary diagram has also been computed to represent the thermodynamic tendency for general grain boundaries in CuO-doped TiO2 to disorder. Experiments have verified the model predictions. In general, these computed grain boundary diagrams can be used to guide the design of optimal sintering recipes. In this NSF project, such grain boundary diagrams have also been computed for several tungsten based binary and ternary refractory alloys, which can be utilized to determine the relative effectiveness of various sintering aids. The knowledge generated from this NSF project will help to predict and control the activated sintering processing of both refractory alloys and functional ceramics, with applications in energy, aerospace, automotive, and other industries. As one specific example of many potential industrial applications, low-temperature sintering of titanium dioxide or other dielectric materials have important applications in the so-called "low-temperature co-fired ceramic (LTCC)" technology to fabricate capacitors, inductors, resistors, transformers, and hybrid circuits. This NSF project has inspired, educated, and mentored nine undergraduate researchers and six Hispanic high-school students via involving them in this cutting-edge research. The principle investigator and graduate students working on this project also hosted lab tours during the UCSD Engineering Exploration Day to introduce this NSF project and related research facilities to community high-school and middle-school students with diversifying background.
